body:
For the record, I have managed to solve all 3 in my own project by subclassing `TestCaseAttribute` and `TestCaseSourceAttribute`, but:
1. This requires that I create my own implementation of every test case builder shipped with nunit.framework. I haven't rebuilt `ValueSourceAttribute`, for example.
2. This unfortunately requires either complete duplication of the NUnit attribute classes, or subclassing and using reflection to access the internal field `TestMethod.params`. I haven't found another way to do this.

Is this something that NUnit itself can handle?

It's fairly well-known that NUnit neither requires nor creates unique test names. As a user, you can set the name of every testcase to "MyTest" and NUnit will happily run them. Of course, this raises the problem that the test then becomes very difficult to identify in the output.

You propose three improvements:
1. "Introspecting arrays" By this do you mean that the array should be represented by listing it's contents?
2. "Explicit test names made local to their methods" By specifying template arguments in the name, this is already possible, e.g.: "{m}_Some_Suffix"
3. "Strings not truncated" "{m}{a}" or "limit increased" "{m}{a:100}

So of the three - and assuming I understand what you are suggesting - the first is a possible change, while the other three are already available.

1. Yes

2, 3.: Wait, what? Where is this documented? I haven't heard of this feature before.
Looks like `{m}{a}` is still truncated, but `{m}{a:100}` does increase the truncation limit.

The specification we worked from is here: https://github.com/nunit/dev/wiki/Generation-of-Test-Names

It should have been transfered to the documentation wiki! I'll make a note of that.

I'll have to look more closely at the code to see what {a} is supposed to do - I was referring to it from memory.

> Note that in this usage, it will generally only make sense to use `{m}`, `{a}` or `{o}` specifiers. However, NUnit will use whatever is provided.

`{o}` isn't mentioned anywhere else on that page - do you recall what this one does?

I think it's an older planned format, replaced by {0} through {9}

I don't think all of this is implemented. I'll have to figure that out when I copy some of it to the docs. Code is at https://github.com/nunit/nunit/blob/master/src/NUnitFramework/framework/Internal/TestNameGenerator.cs
@CharliePoole should we mark this as a documentation issue, or is there any coding we should consider for this?
I created nunit/docs#38 for updating the docs. The issue of uniqueness may require more work but it's actually covered in several existing issues.
I am going to close then.

By that do you mean the use of the content of an array in it's representation as an argument?

I think we have that as an issue somewhere, but I'm unable to find it!
Yep. Is it worth creating/duplicating then?
I searched and still can't find it. This issue has the best description, as case 1 above, so I'm re-opening and re-titling it appropriately.

rename.from: TestCase and TestCaseSource make duplicate test names
rename.to: Use array argument contents in name of parameterized tests rather than just array type.

issue.title: Showing the actual value of complex type parameter with NUnit in the reports

repository.name: docs
repository.description: Documentation for all active NUnit projects

issue.body:
Hi guys, 
first forgive me if this is not the right place to ask questions, but to me it is most suitable.

I remember that I've seen somewhere in the web about showing actual value of complex type parameter. Bear with me while I explain what I mean.

With this test:

    [Test]
    public void Post_StakeToDifferetnSelectionsViaBetsBetIdEndpoint_ReturnsCorrectData(
       [ValueSource(typeof(JsonContextCache), nameof(JsonContextCache.RandomThreeUniqueSelecionIds))] string[] selectionIds,
       [ValueSource(typeof(TestData), nameof(TestData.OddStyles))] OddStyle oddStyle, 
       [Values(true, false)] bool logged)

My report is generated as following: 

`Post_StakeToDifferetnSelectionsViaBetsBetIdEndpoint_ReturnsCorrectData(System.String[],European,True)`
This also applies for user defined custom types as well.

What I want to achieve however is showing the actual values of this complex type parameters: 
`Post_StakeToDifferetnSelectionsViaBetsBetIdEndpoint_ReturnsCorrectData(["1","2","3"],European,True)`

Is it possible using nUnit or I am mistaken that I've seeing this in the web?
I've also asked that question on SO - https://stackoverflow.com/questions/47649312/showing-the-actual-value-of-complex-type-parameter-with-nunit-in-the-reports
Thanks,
kuskmen

body:
Hey guys, do you plan implementing this array introspection?

Thanks,
kuskmen

Best guess answer: Low priority features are usually not implemented unless one of the team gets excited about doing it. Contributions are accepted but a change in how we name tests would be a moderately advanced bit of work and so might require somebody familiar with the internals to work with the contributor.

Other way to go: start a discussion and get the priority raised.
I already have the code for that in a custom test attribute. I might see if I can figure out how to upstream it.
